DOC.HEAD: Lucky Turkey Spared the Christmas Banquet Table
DOC.TEXT: A 52-pound turkey once bound for a Christmas banquet table is pecking away in a back yard because an animal control officer didn't have the heart to wring its neck. The turkey was found waddling the streets this week and senior animal control Officer John Gonzales initially hoped to donate it to a group that feeds the homeless. ``Everyone was interested in getting a turkey that large, but no one wanted him alive,'' he said. But no one wanted to kill the bird, especially not Gonzales. So he turned to Beach Charities, a non-profit group that sponsors a Christmas Adopt-a-Pet program. Sharrie Dyer, director of Beach Charities, said she liked the idea of donating a big turkey to feed the homeless. But she hated the idea of playing benefactor and butcher. ``After all,'' she said, ``our mascot is a 7-foot pelican, Long Beak. How would it look for Long Beak to kill a turkey?'' So she bought 20 lifeless turkeys for the Christmas dinners of needy families. And animal control Officers Donna and Paul Clement adopted the gobbler and added him to their menagerie on their ranch near Corona. His name? ``Lotto, of course,'' said Gonzales. ``Because he's so lucky to be alive.''
